unicode.value: Leisure Activities
Juan Pablo Zúñiga
Learning object based on leisure activities which includes speaking and listening practice
master class
closed exercise or problem
real project
didactic game
open problem
conceptual map
Leisure Activities
Talking about Leisure Activities
In this unit, we will discuss some activities that we may do in our free time.
Text and Tasks
Pair Work

Instructions: Walk around the classroom get together with a classmate, spin the wheel and based on the numbers you get, ask each other the corresponding questions. Talk to as many classmates as possible. Finally, share your answers with the whole class.

  1. Who’s your favorite singer?
  2. Who’s your favorite actor?
  3. What’s your favorite song?
  4. What kind of movies do you like?
  5. How often do you go to concerts?
  6. What kind of music do you like?
  7. What’s your favorite song?
  8. What’s your favorite band?
  9. What was the last movie you saw?
  10. Did you do anything for fun last weekend?
  11. Can you play any musical instrument?
  12. Do you like dancing? Why?
  13. Do you know any song in English?
  14. What do you usually do for fun?
  15. Do you like singing?
  16. What kind of music do you hate?
  17. Can you name any bad actors?
  18. Can you name any bad singers?
  19. What’s the worst movie you saw?
  20. Who’s your favorite movie director?
Text and Tasks
Provide instruction on how the cloze activity should be completed. Default text will be entered if there are no changes to this field.

Instructions: Look at the pictures below. They are famous places in Washington, D.C. Then, listen to a tour guide talk about them and number the pictures 1 to 6 as they are mentioned. The Guide does not mention one place. That one must be number 6.
University of Auckland
If this option is checked, submitted answers with different capitalization will be marked as incorrect.

Lincoln Memorial 6  

Washingon Monument 2  

National Arts & Space Museum 4  

The National Gallery   3  

The Capitol 1  

The White House   5
If this option is set, each word will be marked as the learner types it rather than all the words being marked the end of the exercise.

Enter the text for the cloze activity in to the cloze field by either pasting text from another source or by typing text directly into the field.

To select words to hide, double click on the word to select it and click on the Hide/Show Word button below.

More than one possible answer can be defined enclosing them with pipes (|). I.e.: |dog|cat|bird|

If left unchecked a small number of spelling and capitalization errors will be accepted. If checked only an exact match in spelling and capitalization will be accepted.

For example: If the correct answer is Elephant then both elephant and Eliphant will be judged "close enough" by the algorithm as it only has one letter wrong, even if "Check Capitalization" is on.

If capitalization checking is off in the above example, the lowercase e will not be considered a mistake and eliphant will also be accepted.

If both "Strict Marking" and "Check Capitalization" are set, the only correct answer is "Elephant". If only "Strict Marking" is checked and "Check Capitalization" is not, "elephant" will also be accepted.

Lincoln Memorial 6  

Washingon Monument 2  

National Arts & Space Museum 4  

The National Gallery   3  

The Capitol 1  

The White House   5

Washingon Monument
National Arts & Space Museum
The National Gallery
The Capitol
The White House

Cloze exercises are texts or sentences where students must fill in missing words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Select words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge

Write a text using the target vocabulary. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Highlight the target words in the text. Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Highlight the target words in the text. Provide alternatives with the same word stem, but different affixes. It is a good idea to get a colleague to test the test/exercise to make sure there are no surprises!
Enter any feedback you wish to provide the learner with-in the feedback field. This field can be left blank.
DropDown Activity
Provide instruction on how the dropdown activity should be completed.
Now, listen again and match the given descriptions with the corresponding places:

Lincoln Memorial

Not mentioned

Washington Monument

was finished in 1884

National Air & Space Museum

has a piece of rock from the moon

The National Gallery

has European and American art

The Capitol

has the Statue of Freedom on top

The White House

home of John Adams

Use | (the vertical bar) to separate words.

DropDown exercises are texts or sentences where students must select the correct words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Choose words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge
If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Highlight the target words in the text. Provide alternatives with the same word stem, but different affixes. It is a good idea to get a colleague to test the test/exercise to make sure there are no surprises!
Enter any feedback you wish to provide the learner with-in the feedback field. This field can be left blank.
Let’s go to the movies!

Instructions: You want to go to the movies with some friends. Look at the movie showtimes and choose a movie you both want to see.

Useful Language

Would you like to go to a movie?

What’s playing?

How about________?

What time is it playing?

Let’s go at 8:00 p.m.

Where and what time should we meet?

Let’s meet at the mall at 7:30 p.m.

What would you like to do before / after the movie?

Why don’t we have a hamburger?

Sure! That sounds great!
Text and Tasks
Top 5 Sites to Visit in Turkey
Prediction: Watch the video with the sound off and write as many ideas about the video as come to your mind. After that, share your ideas with a classmate.
Text and Tasks
Vocabulary Activation
Provide instruction on how the dropdown activity should be completed.
Instructions: Match the words on the left with their corresponding meanings on the right.

1. mosque

2. dome

3. epitome

4. bazaar

5. jewelry

6. pottery

7. spice

8. myriad

4 a market in a Middle-Eastern country

8 an extremely great number

6 objects made of clay

5 ornaments made of precious stones and metals

7 condiments

2 a rounded type of roof with a circular base

1 a place for Muslim religious ceremonies

3 a perfect example of something

Attentive watching
Provide instruction on how the cloze activity should be completed. Default text will be entered if there are no changes to this field.
Instructions: Watch the video and organize the following statements chronologically. Number them 1 to 8. Compare your answers with a classmate.
University of Auckland
If this option is checked, submitted answers with different capitalization will be marked as incorrect.

7 The palace is also home to the spoon maker’s diamond.

5 Today, visitors can see what is left of the city and the replica of the infamous wooden horse that led to the downfall of the city.

3 [This mosque] is now a museum which showcases the fine frescos and mosaics that cover the interior of the building.

8 Water […] tumbles down the mountain, forming a myriad of pools.

4 The Greeks attacked the Trojans because beautiful Helen was abducted by a Trojan prince.

2 [This mosque] is considered by many to be the epitome of Byzantine architecture.

6 Everybody loves to shop while on holiday.

1 Tourism in Turkey is mainly focused on a variety of archeological and historical sites.

Expansion: Work in groups of three or four. As a group, decide on the top 5 tourist attractions in Costa Rica. Rank them in order of importance. Be ready to present your top 5 to the rest of the class.
If this option is set, each word will be marked as the learner types it rather than all the words being marked the end of the exercise.

The palace is also home to the spoon maker’s diamond.
Today, visitors can see what is left of the city and the replica of the infamous wooden horse that led to the downfall of the city.
[This mosque] is now a museum which showcases the fine frescos and mosaics that cover the interior of the building.
Water […] tumbles down the mountain, forming a myriad of pools.
The Greeks attacked the Trojans because beautiful Helen was abducted by a Trojan prince.
[This mosque] is considered by many to be the epitome of Byzantine architecture.
Everybody loves to shop while on holiday.

Tourism in Turkey is mainly focused on a variety of archeological and historical sites.

Expansion: Work in groups of three or four. As a group, decide on the top 5 tourist attractions in Costa Rica. Rank them in order of importance. Be ready to present your top 5 to the rest of the class.

Cloze exercises are texts or sentences where students must fill in missing words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Select words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

Write a text using the target vocabulary. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Highlight the target words in the text. Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

Enter any feedback you wish to provide the learner with-in the feedback field. This field can be left blank.
Speaking Task

Duration:
20:00
Grouping:
Pair Work

Instructions: Work in pairs and take turns having conversations based on the following prompts.

Prompt 1

I-Student A. Imagine you are a tourist visiting Costa Rica. Then, you meet a Costa Rican and start a conversation. Introduce yourself and ask for the Costa Rican’s personal information. You are on vacation, so you want to know what places you can visit in CR, what you can do here, what are good places to eat, and what are good places to get souvenirs.

I-Student B. Imagine you meet a tourist who is visiting Costa Rica and you start a conversation. Introduce yourself and ask for the tourist’s personal information. This tourist wants to know about the tourist attractions of CR, the activities that people can do, and the places that tourists can visit. Be ready to answer the tourist’s questions.

Prompt 2

II-Student A. Imagine you are on vacation and you want to go to an exciting place in Costa Rica. You are talking with a friend about this. Ask your friend about good places to visit on vacation and good activities that you can do here. With your friend, choose where to go and what to do on your vacation.

II-Student B. Imagine your friend and you are on vacation and you want to go to a nice place in Costa Rica. Give your friend ideas about where to go and what to do on your vacation in CR. With your friend, you need to choose what to do and where to go on this vacation.

Prompt 3

III- Student A. Imagine you are planning to have a trip around the world. You want to visit some of the most popular tourist attractions of the world. Talk to your friend about what countries you want to visit and what you want to do in those places. Your friend and you need to choose where to go and what to do.

III-Student B. Imagine you are planning to have trip around the world with a friend. You don’t know where to go and what to do exactly. Talk to your friend about the countries that you are interested in visiting. Also, talk about what you can do in those countries. Your friend and you need to choose what countries you want to visit and what you want to do in each of those countries.
Text and Tasks
Juan Pablo Zúñiga

Leisure Activities
